Title: RuneScape creator reveals new MMO 10 years in the making
Content:
Sometimes a game makes you feel soothed just by looking at a screenshot, even if itâs not that pretty. So it is with Brighter Shores, the new project from Andrew Gower, creator of hoary old massively multiplayer role-playing game RuneScape.
Along with his brother Paul, Gower did most of the early development work on RuneScape (which launched in 2001) and founded the studio that made it, Jagex. The Gowers cashed out and left Jagex back in 2010, and little has been heard of what Andrew has been up to since. Now we know: Heâs spent much of that time â 10 years, apparently â making another old-school MMO with a comfortingly nerdy grid-based design. (The press release justifiably calls these orderly isometric dioramas Gowerâs âinstantly recognisable style.â)
Brighter Shores will be a free-to-play game with a âcozy, relaxing atmosphere.â Itâs set in and around a peaceful coastal town in the fantasy land of Adothria. Thereâs a heavy focus on crafting, as well as three new character classes to try: Cryoknight, Hammermage, and Guardian. Gower says he aims to reduce the grind typical of this kind of game, and his studio Fen Research plans to offer an âall-inclusiveâ premium pass unlocking additional content rather than a lot of microtransactions.
After all this time, Gower has also finally left Java behind. RuneScape was launched as a browser game written in this humble programming language, and didnât transition to its own client until 2016, after the Gowers had left. But Fen Research has built its own custom engine and programming language for Brighter Shores, called Fenforge. (Geographical trivia: both studio and engine are likely named after the Fens, a marshy flatland area in the east of England that extends north of Cambridge, where both Jagex and Fen Research are based.)
Brighter Shores will be coming to PC and Mac via Steam later this year.

Title: J Loâs new movie looks Titanfall AF
Content:
Jennifer Lopezâs upcoming Netflix movie casts her as a âbrilliant but misanthropic data analyst with a deep distrust of artificial intelligenceâ in the sci-fi action flick Atlas. But the first teaser for Atlas doesnât really get into that relationship with AI or the renegade robot with whom Lopezâs character âshares a mysterious past.â What the teaser does do is raise one question: Who on the production of this movie played a ton of Titanfall?
Atlas may not have official ties to Respawn Entertainmentâs beloved mech shooter, but the vibes are certainly there. The filmâs first look promises orbital mech drops and mech-on-mech action, and its official description hints at an emotional connection to a robot. Thatâs as close as weâll probably ever get to a cinematic adaptation of the Titanfall games.
Oh, also, Lopezâs character is named Atlas Shepherd, which I can only assume was concocted by someone who played a lot of Xbox 360 games in 2007. Atlas was written by Leo Sardarian and Aron Eli Coleite (who had previously written for Star Trek: Discovery and Heroes), and directed by Brad Peyton (San Andreas, Rampage), an avowed fan of the game Lost Planet.
Joining Lopez in Atlas are Simu Liu (Barbie, Shang-Chi), Oscar nominee Sterling K. Brown (American Fiction, Black Panther), Lana Parrilla (Once Upon a Time), and Mark Strong (Kingsman: The Secret Service).
Atlas drops on Netflix on May 24.

Title: Scream brings back Neve Campbell as franchise returns to the drawing board, again
Content:
Scream is a franchise in free fall. After two successful quasi-reboot sequels, and a plan to seemingly move away from the seriesâ roots, it seems that Spyglass Media is bringing Neve Campbell back to Scream. The actor announced her return to the series on Tuesday, but didnât provide any further details on what the story of Scream 7 would be.
After an incredibly successful 2022 retooling, which brought in new franchise stars like Melissa Barrera and Jenna Ortega, the franchise has suffered one misstep after another. The trouble started in 2023, with the release of Scream VI, which while still a fairly substantial hit at the box office, got slightly more tepid reception than the previous entry. 
For many fans, one of the most disappointing elements of the movie was the sidelining of seriesâ protagonist Sidney Prescott (Campbell), who had been in every previous film. This time around, the seriesâ other regular, Gale Weathers (Courteney Cox), was forced to simply handwave Sidneyâs absence in a throwaway line of dialogue. As it turns out, however, Campbell refused to do the movie because she felt that the studioâs salary offer was too low, given her importance and history with the franchise. 
Despite fans missing Sidney, when Spyglass Media announced plans for Scream 7, which would bring back the main characters from the last two movies, expectations and excitement were still high â not least of all because the fabulous Christopher Landon (Happy Death Day) was being brought on to direct the new entry. 
However, shortly into production, Spyglass unceremoniously fired Barrera, the star of the previous two movies, over her posts about the Israel-Gaza conflict, which the studio deemed antisemitic. Shortly after, Ortega left the project as well. While scheduling differences were the only reason given, it seems very odd that the movie wouldnât reschedule to accommodate one of the biggest stars in the world. Finally, Landon left shortly after Barreraâs firing, leaving the project with no stars and no director. At least until now. 
Campbell announced her return to the series on Instagram on Tuesday, and the writer and creator of the original movie, Kevin Williams, has announced that heâll be directing the new entry. Guy Busick, who co-wrote the previous two movies, will handle the writing on Scream 7. While so much of this feels like a franchise reboot, with two of the original key players returning to the franchise, itâs highly unclear what this new movie might be about. On top of that, thereâs no word which members of the cast from the previous movie might return.

Title: X-Men â97âs showrunner has been fired a week before its premiere
Content:
As a rule, things are never easy for the X-Men â something that seems to apply in real life as well as comic books. In a shocking update from The Hollywood Reporter, Beau DeMayo, creator and showrunner of the highly-anticipated X-Men â97 animated series on Disney Plus, has been fired a week before the showâs March 20 premiere. 
According to THR, DeMayo, who had just finished scripting season 2 of X-Men â97, was suddenly fired last week, and will no longer participate in the showâs promotion. No reason was given for the termination from either Marvel nor DeMayoâs representatives. Polygon has reached out to Disney for comment, but has not received anything at time of publication. 
X-Men â97 is the biggest release on the Disney Plus calendar this month, a continuation of the Fox Kids runaway hit X-Men: The Animated Series that picked up right where the old show left off after its 76-episode run concluded in September 1997. Despite numerous delays, the series has already been renewed for a second season â and, prior to DeMayoâs firing, a third was reportedly being contemplated. 
X-Men â97 is currently scheduled to premiere its 10-episode first season on Disney Plus March 20.

Title: Overwatch 2âs Cowboy Bebop crossover is now live
Content:
Overwatch 2âs second anime crossover event will bring the characters (and music) of Cowboy Bebop to the team-based hero shooter on March 12, Blizzard Entertainment announced Thursday. The collab will add new Cowboy Bebop-inspired skins, emotes, highlight intros, and more to Overwatch 2, including an Ein skin for Wrecking Ball that all players will be able to unlock for free.
The other confirmed characters getting Cowboy Bebop-inspired looks include Cassidy as Spike Spiegel, Ashe as Faye Valentine (with a Red Tail-inspired BOB), Sombra as Ed, and Mauga as Jet Black. Blizzard and anime studio Sunrise originally revealed stylized artwork of those characters, and later revealed the in-game versions of the five heroes reimagined as Cowboy Bebop characters.
In a new gameplay trailer released Monday, we even get to hear some of the collabâs new voice lines, including Ashe delivering the familiar âSee you, space cowboyâ line.
âWeâre honored to be collaborating with one of the most respected anime series of all time in Cowboy Bebop,â Overwatch 2 associate director Aimee Dennett said in a statement. âThis collaboration is a wonderful way to pay homage to the legendary stories, art, animation, and music of the Cowboy Bebop series. We hope its fans and our players have as much fun with what weâre bringing to Overwatch 2 as we did in creating it.â
Overwatch 2âs first anime collab was with One Punch Man, and brought characters like Saitama, Genos, Terrible Tornado, and Mumen Rider to the world of Overwatch. That crossover event ran for about a month in-game, and required players to complete challenges to unlock free cosmetics.
You can get a sneak preview of the Cowboy Bebop Overwatch 2 skins in the gallery below. Cowboy Bebop is currently streaming on Crunchyroll in select territories.
Pricing for Overwatch 2âs Cowboy Bebop cosmetics is now live. Hereâs what the whole collab costs:
Individual Legendary skins cost 1,900 Overwatch Coins each.
Overwatch 2 is available to play for free on Nintendo Switch, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Windows PC, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X.

Title: Zweihander, the RPG engine behind Flames of Freedom, has risen from the dead
Content:
Zweihander: Grim and Perilous RPG, the original tabletop system at the core of groundbreaking titles like Flames of Freedom and Blackbirds, is back on the market. A new crowdfunding campaign for the gameâs second iteration, dubbed Zweihander Reforged Edition, launches today. Polygon sat down with creator Daniel D. Fox to learn more â including how things almost went completely off the rails back in 2022.
Itâs not often that a new tabletop role-playing game can muscle past the Dungeons & Dragons of the world, but thatâs just what happened for Zweihander. After taking home the gold Ennie award for best game in 2018, the Kansas City author and designer parlayed his win into a role at Andrews McMeel Universal as the director of the companyâs fledgling games division. Then, just a few years later, everything â including his role with the company â fell apart. The reason? Fox tells Polygon it had a lot to do with the price of paper at the time.
âEven though we were exceeding our projections on revenues,â Fox said, âthis is a 30-person company with a new [line of] business. Theyâre great at what they do. Theyâre not great at new business. So I had a long discussion with the president of publishing, and he [decided we should] wind this down.â
The news came at an inopportune time on the tail end of the pandemic, just as interest in non-D&D tabletop RPGs began to accelerate. It also torpedoed, for a time, the production of another high-profile crowdfunding success, Into the Mother Lands. And while that project quickly found a new home with Green Ronin, Zweihander itself continued to hover on the brink. That is, until Fox met up with the team at World of Game Design.
âZweihander falls beneath the World of Game design umbrella,â Fox said, âso they are the owner and the publisher.â
Fox still has plenty of creative control, however. Together with collaborators Kate Bullock and Anna Goldberg, Fox is in the process of putting the finishing touches on the revised game â work that heâs been forced to sideline for far too long.
âWe had all this community feedback, from all of these playtesters,â Fox said. âWe kind of collected all this information over the last six, seven years, from people who had been playing Zweihander, and there are a lot of things that we wanted to change, too.â 
In addition to revised and more colorful art, Fox said that much of the gameâs flavor text is also being rewritten for modern audiences. The game also takes an even more aggressive stance on character death. 
âWhatâs interesting about Zweihander is most RPGs really focus on the kind of zero-to-hero momentum,â Fox said. âSo D&D, Pathfinder, those are great games. I play them. I love them. But [...] what if it wasnât zero-to-hero and zero-to-one? What if you played flawed, tragic characters who werenât trying to change the world, but the world was trying to change them? And then what would that journey look like for that character â or in this case, we call them survivors. What would that journey look like for the survivor if they were kind of fighting against these evils and these things that are trying to turn them almost into the monsters they were fighting themselves?â
You can learn more about Zweihander Reforged Edition at the campaign page, which includes a link to a free âsession zeroâ quickstart document. The campaign runs now through April 7, with delivery expected by Feb. 2025.

Title: Warner holds on to Studio Ghibli movies, thanks to multiyear Max streaming deal
Content:
Hereâs a minor win for fans of Good Things who also subscribe to Max: the Studio Ghibli collection will remain on streaming for the foreseeable future. 
Over the last year, media conglomerate Warner Bros. Discovery has become the emblem of cutthroat restructuring in an already tumultuous entertainment landscape. Under CEO David Zaslav, the company has buried Warner Bros. movies like Batgirl and Coyote vs. Acme for tax purposes, licensed classic HBO content to Netflix, partnered with Disney and Fox to create a sports streaming service, gutted (then reconsidered) Turner Classic Movies, delisted indie games on Steam as it openly pivots its gaming division to a free-to-play strategy, and put all its chips on James Gunn to save the DC movie and TV properties. The decisions ruffled artistsâ feathers and sent a fog over the brandâs many studios, the future left frustratingly unclear.
But someone upstairs really loves Hayao Miyazakiâs films. Theyâve been deemed important enough to lock down on the Max service.
Max and GKIDS, one of the great animation distributors operating today, announced on Tuesday that the 2020 deal that brought the Studio Ghibli library to streaming for the first time â including all of master Hayao Miyazakiâs films â has been reupped in a âmultiyear agreement.â (A representative for Max declined to share specifics around the deal with Polygon.) Films like My Neighbor Totoro, Spirited Away, Kikiâs Delivery Service, and The Tale of the Princess Kaguya were all part of the original, unprecedented deal four years ago, which saw the collection come to streaming for the first time alongside the launch of the HBO Max service. Time has passed, mergers have occurred, and rebranding efforts have morphed HBO Max into just Max, but the good news is that the Ghibli movies remain â and will stay in streaming circulation at least until 2025.
The announcement also notes that Miyazakiâs Oscar-winning film The Boy and the Heron is included in the deal, and will premiere on Max âlater this year.â Positioned as Miyazakiâs final film, The Boy and the Heron won big at the 96th Academy Awards earlier this month, though the director was not on hand to receive the award. His longtime producer and Ghibli cofoudner Toshio Suzuki later issued this statement, delivered via a translator backstage at the Oscars, in response to the win.  
âThis was a truly difficult project to bring to completion,â he wrote. âI am very appreciative that the work that was created after overcoming these difficulties has been received by so many people around the world and has received this recognition. Both Hayao Miyazaki and I have aged considerably. I am grateful to receive such an honor at my age. And taking this as a message to continue our work, I will devote myself to work harder in the future. Thank you very much.â
For more on the legacy of Studio Ghibli, read our guide to the studioâs expansive work.

Title: Star Wars Jedi director starts new studio with a bunch of ex-Respawn talent
Content:
Game director Stig Asmussen, who left Respawn Entertainment last fall after making two games for publisher Electronic Arts, has a new studio. Itâs called Giant Skull, and heâs bringing a long list of ex-Respawn talent with him to his new venture.
Asmussenâs credits include Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order, its sequel, and multiple God of War games. So it should be no surprise then that his new company is described as âdedicated to building gameplay-driven, story immersed action-adventure games set in captivating worlds.â Giant Skullâs first untitled project is a âAAA single-player-focused action-adventure,â built in Unreal Engine 5, the developer said in a news release announcing the studio.
Joining Asmussen at Giant Skull are other veteran game developers from Epic Games, Riot Games, and Rocksteady Studios, including: Jon Carr, technical director on Star Wars Jedi: Survivor; Patrick Murphy, an art director who worked on Fortnite, Valorant, League of Legends, and God of War; Lauren McLemore, a lead producer on Fortnite; Jeff Magers, design director on the Star Wars Jedi games; and Brian Campbell, formerly animation director at Epic Games.
âWe have assembled a talented team renowned for immersive storytelling, heroic combat and exhilarating traversal, and our goal is to craft a rich universe that players will want to lose themselves in for years to come,â Asmussen said in a statement.
âWe want players to join us on every step of this amazing journey, as we pave the way for our upcoming game,â said Anthony Scott, COO/CFO of Giant Skull, and formerly director of operations at Rocksteady Studios and head of Unbroken Studios. âWeâre creating something special and have been fortunate enough to assemble an incredible initial team of developers who are extremely passionate and experienced in creating genre-defining, third person action-adventures.â
Giant Skullâs announcement comes just a few weeks after mass layoffs at publisher Electronic Arts, which also canceled Respawnâs in-development first-person shooter set in the Star Wars universe. Asmussenâs new studio also comes amid severe cutbacks at studios and publishers across North America and Europe; thousands of video game workers have lost their jobs this year, following a similarly dour year for employment in the industry.

Title: New Helldivers 2 patch means changing the way you take on super-armored Terminids
Content:
If youâre one of the Helldivers 2 players whoâve been struggling to take on the gameâs powerful Terminids â specifically, Chargers and Bile Titans â youâre in luck. Arrowhead Game Studios published a patch on Tuesday that tweaks the spawn rates of those two bugs. Crucially, Arrowhead said it hasnât changed the overall difficulty: There will be fewer of these heavily armored enemies, but other bugs will show up âin greater numbers,â according to the patch notes.
Helldivers 2 players have been strategizing online how to take on Chargers (the massive Terminids that may as well be tanks) and Bile Titans (which are the supercharged, leggy versions of the Bile Spewers). The jump in difficulty from other enemies to these is pretty significant, and people have struggled to take them down reliably. Players have found ways to take on the enemies â i.e. the âlega meta,â where people target a weak spot in the legs â but Arrowhead doesnât want players to have to use their âheavy anti-tank weapons on legs instead of the obvious weak point.â Thatâs why, in addition to reducing the spawn rate of Chargers and Bile Titans on difficulty 7 and up, Arrowhead has lowered the health of the Chargerâs head, making it a good place to target with powerful weapons.

    Related
  
âTogether with the unfortunately undocumented change of last patch that increased the armor penetration ability of less well placed shots for EAT-17s and Recoilless Rifle shots, Chargers should now be easier to handle by well equipped groups,â Arrowhead said.
Alongside the Terminid tweaks, Helldivers 2 players can expect a couple of UI, voiceover, and bug fixes, too. Arrowhead has also removed the âElectronic Countermeasuresâ operation modifier. (Technically, it was removed in the last patch, but Arrowhead didnât mention it in the patch notes.) The studio is looking to rework the modifier: âWe found that this modifier wasnât communicated clearly enough and overall caused more frustration than excitement with the way it was currently implemented,â Arrowhead said.
Arrowhead ended its patch notes with a list of known issues in Helldivers 2, including an issue that causes the game to crash when using a stim inside an Exosuit. Hereâs the full list, straight from Arrowhead:

Title: The Ghostbusters are coming to Destiny 2 ahead of the new movie
Content:
Bungieâs latest Destiny 2 pop culture crossover is nearly here. But this time it isnât skins or armor sets from another video game, itâs items from an upcoming movie â Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire, to be precise.
On Monday, Bungie revealed on X, formerly Twitter, that three Ghostbusters-themed cosmetics are coming to Destiny 2. Thereâs a Guardian ship based on the infamous Ecto-1 car, a Ghost shell based on the franchisesâ most recognizable ghost, Slimer, and a Sparrow that seems to take inspiration from the main villain of Frozen Empire. All of these cosmetics are coming to Destiny 2 on March 19, just three days before Ghostbusters: Frozen Empire hits theaters.
As for the cost of these items, Bungie hasnât revealed anything yet. However, going off of previous bundles, it seems likely this pack will cost anywhere from 2200 Silver (about $20) to 2800 Silver (about $30). Previous packs that include a Sparrow, ship, and Ghost shell only run 2200 Silver (often reduced to only 1900 during sales), but last yearâs pack based on The Witcher franchise ran for 2800 (2500 on sale).
This is the latest in a long line of cosmetic crossovers for Bungie and Destiny 2. It all started with Fortnite back in 2022. Since then Bungie has added PlayStation mascots like Kratos from God of War to the game, and even items inspired by Assassinâs Creed and The Witcher. Most recently, Guardians were able to pick up armor based on the Mass Effect franchise, which also came with a free ship, Sparrow, and Ghost. 
The Ghostbusters crossover does seem a bit different than the other crossovers. First, it isnât drawing primary inspiration from another game â although The Witcher obviously also has a popular Netflix show. Second, there are no Ghostbuster armor sets for players to purchase and wear. As far as Bungie has revealed, this Ghostbusters collaboration only includes the two vehicles and the Ghost. So any Guardians hoping to suit up with their own Proton Pack or Venkman jumpsuit appear to be out of luck.

Title: Lego unveils three big Super Mario sets coming in August
Content:
Lego has three new Super Mario sets launching on Aug. 1, and it teased Mario Kart sets coming in 2025. While it only showed a silhouette of Marioâs signature kart, itâs pretty exciting nevertheless. As for 2024 releases, Lego dropped a bunch of details on new sets as part of Nintendoâs annual Mario Day celebration. With every release, it seems like the possibility for antics multiplies. Case in point: Roy, King Boo, and Bowser star in these upcoming sets.
The Bowser Express Train set (shown above) is a big 1,392-piece set thatâll be on sale for $119.99. It comes with everything needed to stage an assault on the Mushroom Kingdom, including a cannon, a Hammer Bro, and an fiendish look thatâs sure to make any nearby Toads and Toadettes run in circles (Toads and Toadettes not included). Unrelated to the assault, it serves as transportation for some very dignified Goombas who simply wish to go from place to place in style. 
All that the King Booâs Haunted Mansion set needs to turn into a Luigiâs Mansion simulator is a Luigi figure from his starter course. This 932-piece set costs $74.99, and includes his majesty, King Boo, a smaller, more bashful Boo, along with Dry Bones and a yellow baby Yoshi. As with other expansion sets, youâll need one of the original Mario, Luigi, or Peach starter set figures to fully experience this one. The figures included in those can scan the barcode-like objects that allow them to collect coins, stars, or perform an action. Alternatively, you can just use your imagination.
Lastly, we have Battle with Roy at Peachâs Castle, a 738-piece set that costs $64.99. Itâs a stunning replica of Peachâs Castle, as depicted in Super Mario 64. Unfortunately, Roy, one of Bowserâs underling Koopas, has arrived to stir up trouble. Toad doesnât look particularly fazed, perhaps knowing that, with a Mario, Luigi, or Peach figure there, things shouldnât get too out of hand.
As mentioned before, buying a starter course is the best way to experience these upcoming expansions. The starter courses are the only way to get your hands on the Mario, Peach, or Luigi figures that possess barcode readers on their feet that help expansion courses come to life. You can use them to collect coins, unlock boxes, stomp on enemies, and ultimately âwinâ at each course. To configure them, youâll need to use the Lego Super Mario mobile app.
Thankfully, for a limited time, many Super Mario courses (including starter courses) are discounted for Mario Day. Hereâs the full selection at Amazon.

Title: MultiVersus returns in May, nearly a year after going offline
Content:
Fighting game MultiVersus, the Smash Bros.-like that merged the worlds of DC Comics, Game of Thrones, Looney Tunes, and other Warner Bros.-owned properties, will relaunch on May 28, developer Player First Games announced Monday. MultiVersus has been offline since June 2023, when the developer took the game down to retool it.
Tony Huynh, co-founder and CEO of Player First, said in a video announcement that MultiVersus has been rebuilt in Unreal Engine 5, which will give the platform fighter a new and improved look. The team has also ârebuilt the game from the ground up to support our new netcode,â Huynh said, and that players can expect âpinpoint accuracyâ and âconsistent game performance, no matter what platform youâre playing on.â
Player First is also âadding some really exciting, brand-new personalities to the roster,â Huynh said, but did not provide specifics on which Warner Bros.-owned characters will come to MultiVersus later this year.
The studio is also adding a brand-new PvE mode, which Huynh says will give players unique rewards.
MultiVersus launched in July 2022, in what Warner Bros. and developer Player First Games called an âopen beta.â In March 2023, the studio announced it was pulling the game from digital stores and taking it offline. At the time, it was the first official update that the studio had provided since November 2022, when Player First brought Marvin the Martian and season 2 content to the game. In the following months, players expressed discontent at the cadence of new characters and other additions.
Over the past eight months, MultiVersus players have only had access to the gameâs offline modes: the training room (aka The Lab) and local matches. The studio promised MultiVersus would return, however, as it developed new characters, maps, and modes, as well as updated netcode and matchmaking improvements.
MultiVersus will become available again for the platforms it was previously released for: PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Windows PC, Xbox One, and Xbox Series X.

Title: Thereâll be some kind of new Super Mario Bros. movie in 2026
Content:
The Super Mario Bros. Movie will be getting a sequel... of some sort. Nintendo and animation studio Illumination have announced that theyâre re-teaming on a second film âbased on the world of Super Mario Bros.â to be released on April 3, 2026.
In a note shared on X by the official Nintendo account, Mario creator (and now, movie producer) Shigeru Miyamoto said of the new movie, âWeâre thinking about broadening Marioâs world further, and itâll have a bright and fun story.â
The wording suggests that the film might expand beyond the first movieâs focus on Mario and Luigi and perhaps bring other characters to the fore, but for now, thereâs little to go on. Little, that is, apart from The Super Mario Bros. Movieâs post-credits scene, which strongly suggested Yoshi would play a big part in the sequel.
In other ways, Nintendo, Illumination, and distributor Universal Pictures arenât messing with the formula that brought in over $1.3 billion at the worldwide box office in 2023, making The Super Mario Bros. Movie the second biggest release of the year after Barbie. The core creative team behind the new movie will be exactly the same: directors Aaron Horvath and Michael Jelenic and screenwriter Matthew Fogel. The release strategy is a match, too: The Super Mario Bros. Movie also came out in early April (on April 5, 2023, to be exact).
Thereâs no word on casting yet, although it would be surprising if Chris Pratt didnât return to the role of Mario (assuming Mario is actually in this one).
In a video shared to celebrate March 10 (âMAR10 dayâ), Illumination CEO Chris Meledandri said that the companyâs Paris studio was deep into storyboarding and set-building work on the movie, and would begin animation soon.
Before then, though, the studio has Despicable Me 4 â the sixth film starring its world-conquering Minions â coming on on July 4.

Title: The biggest moments from the 2024 Oscars
Content:
The Oscars is one of the biggest â if not the biggest â nights in the American entertainment industry every year, and the 2024 Oscars were no different. All the stars were out tonight, from Best Actor nominees like Jeffrey Wright, Paul Giamatti, and Cillian Murphy to Best Director nominees like Christopher Nolan, Martin Scorsese, and Jonathan Glazer.
The night always kicks off before the event officially starts, with some absolutely killer red carpet moments (and this year, a very good dog made a special appearance). Best Supporting Actress DaâVine Joy Randolph and The Zone of Interest director Jonathan Glazer gave some powerful speeches. Billie Eilish and Ryan Gosling brought the Barbie soundtrack to life. The Boy and the Heron beat out some worthy competitors for Best Animated Feature.
Oh, also John Cena got naked! 
In case you missed the three-hour-long broadcast â or you just want to relive some of the best moments â here are the biggest moments from the 2024 Academy Awards. 
No need to worryâMessi, good boy and star of âAnatomy of a Fall,â has arrived at the #Oscars. : https://t.co/sLzfVpOVJj pic.twitter.com/CSo5dTd7Jy
The Oscars is all about deciding who is the yearâs best actor, actress, and director, but one question thatâs somehow eluded the Academy until this year: Whoâs a good boy? Or rather, who is the yearâs goodest boy? Messi the dog from Anatomy of a Fall, thatâs who! There was a bit of uncertainty if everyoneâs favorite pooch was coming to this yearâs ceremony, but luckily, Messi was able to clear his busy schedule to make an appearance at Hollywoodâs biggest night.
Itâs expected that if youâre walking the red carpet for the Oscars, you need to show up in your most eye-popping formal attire. Nimona star and former Try Guy Eugene Lee Yang showed up tonight intent to take home the honor for this yearâs most attention-grabbing ensemble: An elegant red suit jacket complimented with a long flowing dress bottom. 
DaâVine Joy Randolph gave a moving speech while accepting the award for Best Supporting Actress for her role in Alexander Payneâs The Holdovers. Co-star Paul Giamatti, who walked DaâVine up to the stage when her name was announced, shed visible tears as Randolph talked about the power of being seen, accepted, and celebrated for her worth and thanking her mother, teachers, and publicists for guiding and supporting her in her career.
While this yearâs Best Animated Feature category was stacked with terrific nominees, Spider-Man: Across The Spider-Verse and Hayao Miyazakiâs The Boy and the Heron were the films most favored to win the prestigious award. After months of anticipation, The Boy and the Heron was finally revealed to be this yearâs winner for Best Animated Feature. 
His first feature-length animated film in over a decade, The Boy and the Heron marks Miyazakiâs second time winning the award for Best Animated Feature after his landmark win for 2001âs Spirited Away.
Cord Jefferson accepted the award for Best Adapted Screenplay for his work on American Fiction. In his speech, Jefferson took a moment to call out Hollywood studios to take more chances on original films like American Fiction. âI understand this is a risk-averse industry,â Jefferson said. âBut instead of making one $200 million movies, try making ten $20 million movies. The next Scorsese is out there, the next Nolan is out there; they just want a shot.â
Billie Eilish took the stage with her brother and collaborator Finneas OâConnell for a stirring orchestral rendition of her song âWhat Was I Made For?â from the Barbie soundtrack. The song is nominated for this yearâs Best Original Song alongside fellow Barbie track âIâm Just Ken.â 
John Cena at the #Oscars stage. pic.twitter.com/735IsDTbC3
The male body is not a joke, Jimmy Kimmel.
And in case you were wondering... yes, he really was buns out.
Yep, Cenaâs actually naked #OSCAR pic.twitter.com/SDh4kie5FO
Jonathan Glazer accepts the Best International Feature Oscar for The Zone Of Interest: âAll our choices were made to reflect and confront us in the present. Our film shows where dehumanisation leads at its worst.â He goes on to relate that to the dehumanisation happening in theâ¦ pic.twitter.com/qwPXxk7SVC
Jonathan Glazer took time in his acceptance speech for Best International Feature on behalf of The Zone of Interest to call out the historical parallels between the events of the Holocaust drama and the ongoing humanitarian crisis of the Israeli-Palestine conflict. âAll our choices were made to reflect and confront us in the present,â Glazer said. âOur film shows where dehumanization leads at its worst.â
In a career first, Robert Downey Jr. won the award for Best Supporting Actor for his performance as Lewis Strauss in Christopher Nolanâs Oppenheimer.  âIâd like to thank my terrible childhood, and the Academy, in that order,â Downey said. âIâd like to thank my veterinarian â I meant, wife, Susan Downey. She found me a snarling rescue pet, and loved me back to life.â
Wake up babe: the new #Oscars meme just dropped! #Oscars2024 #AnatomyofaFall pic.twitter.com/5TjAhAQ3J2
Dâaww, whoâs a good boy? Messiâs a good boy!
Light the Bat-Signal! Arnold Schwarzenegger and Danny DeVito have taken to the stage to present the Oscar for Visual Effects."We both tried to kill Batman," joked Schwarzenegger... cut to Michael Keaton in the audience   #Oscars2024   Getty Images pic.twitter.com/XwpCW6Rbgg
âBatman, that son of a bitch.â 
With plastic Godzilla toys in hand, the visual effects team for Godzilla Minus One and Director Takashi Yamazaki took to the Oscars stage to accept this yearâs award for Best Visual Effects. In a moving speech, Yamazaki compared his team to the underdog efforts of Rocky Balboa â beating the odds to prove that no matter what, everyone has a chance.
Director Mstyslav Chernov accepts the Best Documentary Feature Oscar for 20 Days In Mariupol: âThis is the first Oscar in Ukrainian history. And Iâm honoured. But probably Iâll be the first director on this stage who will say, 'I wish I never made this film'. I wish I couldâ¦ pic.twitter.com/UVRiE24VKM
20 Days in Mariupol director Mstyslav Chernov took to the stage to accept the award for this yearâs best Documentary Feature. In his acceptance speech, Chernov called attention to the auspiciousness of the Oscar win â the first in Ukrainian history â and expressed his sincerest wish that the history of the Russian-Ukrainian war is told and remembered truthfully. 
âIâll be the first director on this stage who will say, âI wish I never made this filmâ,â Chernov said. âI wish I could exchange this for Russia never attacking Ukraine, never occupying our cities. I cannot change the history, I cannot change the past. But all together â among you, some of the most talented people in the world â we can make sure the record is set straight, and the truth will prevail. And that the people of Mariupol and those who have given their lives will never be forgotten. Cinema forms memories, and memories form history.â
John Mulaney explaining the entire plot to Field of Dreams instead of presenting his category at the Oscars lol. king pic.twitter.com/5q98HfH5ur
After extolling some great lines of cinema (including âHe was in the Amazon with my mom when she was researching spiders right before she diedâ), John Mulaney went into a rapid-fire SparkNotes rundown of the plot of Field of Dreams, using the phrase âghost baseballâ several times more than any Oscar ceremony on record. 
In a sparkly pink suit, Ryan Gosling started to croon Kenâs big anthem from the audience, before he took the the stage with a group of fellow Kens. It was bright and pink, with big Barbie face props and some karate chops. Also, Slash from Guns Nâ Roses! 
Greta Gerwig being a proud mom and running up to Billie Eilish and Finneas after their Oscar win is so cute pic.twitter.com/vkHYEXhoOp
Billie Eilish and Finneas accepted the Oscar for Best Original Song for âWhat Was I Made For?â In an emotional speech, Eilish thanked director Margot Robbie and everyone who was deeply affected by Barbie and the song. With this win, Billie Eilish became the first woman to win the âTriple Crownâ (Oscar, Grammy, and Golden Globe) for a work of film music twice.
Christopher Nolan took home the award for Best Director on behalf of Oppenheimer. In his acceptance speech, Nolan thanked his wife and producer Emma Thomas, and commented on how honored he felt to be considered a part of cinemaâs century-long legacy. âWe donât know where this incredible journey is going from here, but to know that you think Iâm a meaningful part of it means the world to me.â Then, they played him off to Hans Zimmerâs Pirates of the Caribbean theme. Weird!
For her role as Bella Baxter in Poor Things, Emma Stone won the award for Best Actress, tearfully accepting the award (and pointing out to the presenters that her dress broke, probably some time during the âIâm Just Kenâ performance). Stone looked incredibly surprised to accept the award, especially when up against Lily Gladstone and Sandra HÃ¼ller.
âItâs not about me,â Stone said, referring to what Poor Things director Yorgos Lanthimos advised her about a possible acceptance speech. âItâs about a team that came together to make something greater than the sum of its parts. That is the best part of making movies.â
Al Pacino presented the award for Best Picture, announcing Oppenheimerâs win in a trail of syllables that everyone in the audience was able to make out just well enough for the winners to take the stage. Producer Emma Thomas Nolan gave the acceptance speech, thanking the Academy, her children, and her husband Christopher Nolan. âThe reason this movie is the movie it was, was Chris Nolan. Heâs singular, heâs brilliantâ¦ and Iâm so grateful for you.â

Title: Christopher Nolan finally won an Oscar
Content:
The Dark Knight was absolutely snubbed for a Best Picture nomination back in 2009, but oh well, at least the Academy Awards wised up on Christopher Nolan. On Sunday night, the purveyor of big-screen entertainment finally won his Oscar for directing the hell out of Oppenheimer. The biopic, which picked up awards throughout the night, was well-positioned going into the ceremony while Nolanâs directing win was anticipated by fans and awards prognosticators alike. After all, the win was a long time coming for the director who has gone surprisingly overlooked by the industryâs biggest awards show.
Nolanâs win comes off a past that includes a scant number of nominations and zero previous wins. The filmmaker was first nominated alongside his brother â and future Fallout TV director â Jonathan Nolan for their work on Memento. The duo lost to Julian Fellows for Gosford Park. 
Hollywood was abuzz in 2008 under the assumption that The Dark Knight would not only earn the director an accolade but break into the Best Picture top five, shattering a belief that superhero stories had no place in the prestigious annals of Oscar history. But it didnât happen. The Oscars would immediately remake itself in order to never whiff that hard again. 
2011âs Inception put Nolan back in the awards conversation, landing him nominations for Best Screenplay and Picture. But still, no love for direction. The man crashed a train through a city street â what more did these people want?! The answer was war movies; Nolanâs lean, mean WWII thriller Dunkirk scored him a spot at the directorâs table, alongside, Guillermo del Toro (The Shape of Water), Greta Gerwig (Lady Bird), Jordan Peele (Get Out), and Paul Thomas Anderson (Phantom Thread). Del Toro took home the prize, but Nolanâs time would come just a few years later.
âMovies are just over 100 years old,â he said in his acceptance speech for Oppenheimer. âI imagine what it was like being 100 years into painting or theater. We donât know where that incredible journey is going from here, but to know that you think that I am a meaningful part of it means the world to me.â
Nolan arrives at his Oppenheimer moment not just as an accomplished filmmaker, but as a vocal industry leader for the theatrical experience, shooting on celluloid, blowing things up in real life, projecting on IMAX, and how much it sucked when Warner Bros. put all of its movies on HBO Max for an entire year. He has ruffled feathers over the years and rarely pandered, which may be the reason it took so long for him to score at the personality-driven Academy Awards. But that commitment to the craft created a cult of personality around him that has gone far beyond the usual film nerd community; during a summer of blockbusters, more people showed up for his three-hour historical biopic than the umpteenth Transformers movie. His Oscar win is a win for artists grappling with a business that seems to prefer more... artificial intelligence. 
If The Dark Knight upended expectations, maybe Nolanâs win for Oppenheimer will have a similar effect. As the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences scrambles to figure out how to lure more young folk to the Oscars telecast each year â remember when we almost got a Most Popular category? â and the movie studios sift through their IP file bins for anything toyetic they can throw $200 million at, the solution to the entertainment industryâs many woes seems to be staring everyone in the face. 
Nolan just won an Oscar for doing whatever his heart desired. Imagine if more people got the chance?

Title: The Oscarsâ Iâm Just Ken live performance was much more than Kenough
Content:
During the 2024 Oscars ceremony, Ryan Gosling took to the stage with everyone from Simu Liu to Slash to perform âIâm Just Kenâ â one of the breakout (and award-nominated) songs from Barbie. 
In the movie, âIâm Just Kenâ is a super heightened number, as the Kens rev themselves up for an inter-Ken world, and basically represents their idea of the patriarchy breaking at the seams. The Kens rally to fight each other with sports equipment and hobby horses, a big musical manifestation of their toxic masculinity. Eventually Goslingâs Ken and Simu Liuâs Ken bump chests and the sequence melds into a dream ballet, where the two factions of Kens have an aggressive dance-off. 
During the show, âIâm Just Kenâ started off right after the award for Best Sound, with Ryan Gosling in a sparkly pink suit crooning from behind Margot Robbie. He slowly sauntered up to the stage, joined by a group of dancers in tuxedos, pink sashes, and cowboy hats (including fellow Kens, Simu Liu, Kingsley Ben-Adir, and Ncuti Gatwa). The dancers proceeded to engage in a similar mock fight-dance, with Gosling karate chopping pink pieces of pink wood. Stage awash with pink light, Gosling continued to croon in a sea of giant Barbie face props, before joining Slash from Guns âN Roses rocking out on the guitar. Then, he went down into the audience to get the rest of the Barbie cast in on the action. 
It was, in a word, Kenough. 
âIâm Just Kenâ wasnât the only nominated song from Barbie. Billie Eilishâs âWhat Was I Made For?â, the melancholy number that plays at the end of the movie as Barbie realizes she wants to be more than just an idea, was also on the roster. Eilish and Finneas OâConnell, her brother and frequent collaborator, performed the number earlier in the night. In the end, it was âWhat Was I Made For?â that took home the Oscar gold â but âIâm Just Kenâ certainly was a fun time.

Title: Jimmy Kimmelâs Oscars monologue ended on a moment of union solidarity
Content:
Jimmy Kimmelâs opening monologue for the 2024 Oscars started out pretty run-of-the mill. There were jokes about how Killers of the Flower Moon was long enough to âdrive to Oklahoma and solve the murders yourself,â a Madame Web shoutout, and a pretty good topical gag about the viral Republican rebuttal to the State of the Union address last week. But then Kimmel ended his monologue on something remarkable: a quippy, yet sincere and full-throated speech in support of Hollywoodâs labor unions. 
After the late-night host got some ribbing on the dual WGA and SAG-AFTRA strikes last year with laugh lines both corny (âIf a movie premieres at The Grove and no actors are there to support it, does Mario Lopez make a sound?â) and shockingly barbed (making it clear he wasnât shouting out the Directorâs Guild of America, who âfolded immediatelyâ), Kimmel pivoted to sincerity. Hollywood, Kimmel said, âis at its heart, a union town,â and then proceeded to extend gratitude to the below the line labor unions: the truck drivers, Teamsters, and IATSE union members who supported striking Hollywood talent, calling for those present to support the IATSE in their ongoing negotiations with the studios). 
Last summerâs Hollywood work stoppage began with the Writerâs Guild of America beginning what would be a 148-day strike in May, and continued when SAG-AFTRA, the actorâs union, went on strike two months later, on July 14, for 118 days. At the heart of both union disputes with the studios were protections governing the use of artificial intelligence, as Kimmel noted by way of Transformers: Rise of the Beasts joke. 
Kimmel then called many of those union workers on stage in a genuinely moving demonstration of solidarity, closing out with one final joke: âIâm gonna make sure this show runs long so you get a ton of overtime.â

Title: 600 Activision QA workers unionize, Microsoft voluntarily recognizes
Content:
Hundreds of Activision quality assurance workers are unionizing with the Communications Workers of America (CWA). The union covers approximately 600 Activision central QA workers across three locations: Austin, Texas; Eden Prairie, Minn.; and El Segundo, Calif. This makes the union, called Activision Quality Assurance United - CWA, the largest group of unionized video game workers in the U.S.
The final vote is tallied at 390 votes âyesâ and eight votes âno,â a CWA representative told Polygon.
âSomething we organized around is that in this industry, QA and customer service are the lowest paid jobs, and often looked down upon either within the industry or by customers,â Activision QA tester and organizing committee member Kara Fannon told Polygon. âItâs easy for people to say to QA, âOh, I found a bug,â even though we logged tens of thousands of bugs. So why is QA [unionizing], as opposed to other people in the industry? We have the weakest protections currently and we want to make sure that weâre strong so our work can keep going the way it is â we want to be supporting these games and working really hard on them.â

    Related
  
Activision Quality Assurance United - CWA members work on games published by Activision Publishing, including franchises like Call of Duty, Crash Bandicoot, and Tony Hawk Pro Skater. The group joins unionized Microsoft and Activision Blizzard employees at Blizzard Albany, Raven Software, and ZeniMax. 
The Blizzard Albany and Raven Software unions were brought under Microsoft with the companyâs $68.7 billion Activision Blizzard merger. Previously, ZeniMax Workers United was the largest group of video game industry QA workers at Microsoft and across companies in the U.S. with more than 300 workers.
Like the organizing efforts at ZeniMax, Activision QA workers reportedly did not face the union-busting tactics that were alleged to have occurred during Blizzard Albany and Raven Softwareâs union campaigns. Thatâs because Microsoft signed a labor neutrality agreement with CWA in 2022, which is basically a contract that says Microsoft must stay neutral in all union interactions. Agreements like this are not common, Risa Lieberwitz, professor of Labor Law and Employment Law at Cornellâs School of Industrial Labor and Relations and academic director for IRLâs The Worker Institute, told Polygon in 2023 after ZeniMaxâs union win.
âNow under Microsoft with the neutrality agreement they signed with CWA, itâs a lot easier,â Fannon said. âWe donât have to be concerned about any form of union-busting tactics. Microsoft made sure all managers were trained on neutrality. We knew that if we encountered union busting, we could bring it up so itâs addressed.â
The other positive is that neither Activisionâs QA workers nor Microsoft management have to go through the union election process with the National Labor Relations Board, which can sometimes take a while. Instead, Activision QA workers have been voting since Feb. 22 with either a union authorization card (a document, physical or digital, indicating approval of the union) or a confidential vote through an online portal.
Fannon added that the next step for the union is to enter into bargaining with Microsoft. But first, members will be surveyed to take stock of what issues are most important to the group. âOne great thing about a union is that itâs a democratic process,â Fannon said. âPeople have different ideas of what they want. Some things that are fairly common among people are wanting better pay â here in Minnesota, we donât make what would be considered a living wage.â
Fannon also pointed to better career development opportunities, increased benefits, and job security. Layoffs have created a major crisis for video game industry workers for the past couple years, and Activisionâs QA workers are thinking about their futures, too; better severance packages are important. A union canât always prevent layoffs, but it does empower workers to negotiate for their futures; in February, Sega of Americaâs union workers were able to save 18 jobs and negotiate better severance for those who were laid off. At Microsoft, ZeniMax QA union members were spared from a massive 1,900-person layoff in January. While union status may not have been a factor, some union members think it was.
Once itâs clear what union members want to fight for, theyâll head into negotiations, which entails the union and Microsoft going back and forth on a contract.
The news also means Activision QA workers from across the country are united; members are meeting people they might not otherwise come in contact with. That camaraderie is powerful, even outside of a contract â both in what it does for workplace solidarity, but also as a way to inspire the industry.
âItâs nice to know that everyoneâs gonna hear about this, and that people can be inspired to form their own unions,â Fannon said. âI went to a conference and there were some people who were part of Starbucks Workers United. They were talking and I was feeling so inspired. And then I realized, people might feel that way about what weâre doing. It hasnât really hit about how monumental it is. But it feels really good to be a part of.â 
Update (March 11): A Microsoft representative has provided a statement to Polygon. âWe maintained our commitment to remain neutral during the organizing campaign, and following this vote we recognize the Communications Workers of America (CWA) as the bargaining representative for the Activision Publishing Central Quality Assurance employees,â Microsoft deputy general counsel said. âWe look forward to continuing our positive labor management relationship.â

Title: Aquaria answers, âwhich anime character would win RuPaulâs Drag Race?â
Content:
Aquaria is drag royalty. The drag queen, performer, makeup artist, and model sky-rocketed to fame in 2018 after competing and eventually winning the 10th season of RuPaulâs Drag Race.
They also love anime, having professed their love for shows like PokÃ©mon and Yu-Gi-Oh!, and even cosplaying as Shinji Ikari from Neon Genesis Evangelion. Naturally, Aquaria was one of several dozen celebrities to walk the orange carpet of this yearâs Crunchyroll Anime Awards. 
Polygon had the opportunity to catch up with Aquaria during the event, where we asked them about the anime inspirations behind their fashion sense, their formative anime experiences growing up, and most importantly, which anime character in their opinion would have the best chance of winning RuPaulâs Drag Race? The answer: Team Rocketâs James from PokÃ©mon, duh!
@Aquaria is the expert, but who do you think would win??   #rupaulsdragrace #anime #pokemon 
âObviously James from Team Rocket in PokÃ©mon,â Aquaria told Polygon. âI feel like every episode she has to get into quick drag to go snatch some Pikachu [or other PokÃ©mon]. Her drag is always creative and unique and very nerve-giving and really talented.â
This yearâs Crunchyroll Anime Awards was a star-studded event, featuring appearances from the likes of Megan Thee Stallion, Dallas Cowboys Football star DeMarcus Lawrence, The Marvelsâ Iman Vellani, and more.
